Title: Meeting Darwin's Last Challenge: Toward a Global Tree of Human Languages and Genes

This project aims to tackle the long-standing challenge of correlating language families with classical genetic markers, a prediction first proposed by Charles Darwin. Despite significant advances in molecular biology, current language classification methods are limited in scope and probabilistically unreliable. We propose a novel approach, building on the work of Longobardi and Guardiano (2009), which leverages grammatical evidence and advances in formal and typological linguistics to measure linguistic distances between remote populations with unprecedented standards of testability and replicability. Our collaborative approach brings together linguists and biologists to select significant populations for language and gene sampling. We will utilize powerful genetic tools developed over the last decade, including genome-wide studies of Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms, Y chromosome markers, and mitochondrial DNA markers, and apply biostatistical methods to describe DNA diversity and its relationships to linguistic diversity. By integrating these approaches, we aim to create a global tree of human languages and genes, providing a new understanding of human history and migration patterns. This project has the potential to revolutionize our understanding of the correlation between language and genetic evolution, finally meeting Darwin's last challenge.

Title: Meeting Darwin's Last Challenge: Toward a Global Tree of Human Languages and Genes

This proposal seeks to address a long-standing challenge in the fields of linguistics and genetics: the lack of a robust method for classifying human languages and populations. Despite the rise of molecular biology's contribution to historical classification, current language classification methods are limited in scope and probabilistically unreliable. We propose a novel approach that leverages advances in formal and typological linguistics, as well as powerful genetic tools developed over the last decade. Our method, based on grammatical evidence, offers unprecedented standards of testability and replicability, enabling the measurement of linguistic distances between remote populations. A collaborative approach will bring together linguists and biologists to select significant populations for language and gene sampling. We will employ genome-wide studies of Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms, Y chromosome and mitochondrial DNA markers, and biostatistical methods to describe DNA diversity and interpret its relationships to linguistic diversity. Ultimately, our project aims to fulfill Darwin's prediction of an eventual isomorphy between trees of languages and populations, providing a deeper understanding of human history and migration. By integrating linguistic and genetic data, we will create a global tree of human languages and genes, shedding new light on the complex relationships between language, culture, and genetics.

Title: Meeting Darwin's Last Challenge: Toward a Global Tree of Human Languages and Genes

This proposal seeks to address a long-standing challenge in understanding the relationship between language and genetic evolution. Despite the predictions of Charles Darwin, current methods for classifying languages and populations are limited, with traditional approaches being either too narrow in scope or probabilistically unreliable. Our project proposes a novel approach, building on advances in formal and typological linguistics, to establish a correspondence between language families and classical genetic markers. By combining grammatical evidence with powerful genetic tools, including genome-wide studies of Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms, Y chromosome markers, and mitochondrial DNA markers, we aim to create a global tree of human languages and genes. A collaborative approach between linguists and biologists will ensure the selection of significant populations for language and gene sampling. Our method offers unprecedented standards of testability and replicability, enabling the measurement of linguistic distances between remote populations. This project has the potential to revolutionize our understanding of human evolution and language development, ultimately confirming Darwin's prediction of an isomorphy between trees of languages and populations.
